name: Ch 15: Disruptive, Impulse-Control, and Conduct Disorders

questions.stem: A 10-year-old boy has a 2-year history of frequent temper outbursts, arguing with adults, deliberately annoying others, and blaming others for his mistakes. He has not engaged in physical aggression, property destruction, or serious rule violations. The MOST likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: This presentation meets criteria for Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD): angry/irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, and vindictiveness for ≥6 months. Critically, ODD does NOT involve the serious violations of others' rights seen in Conduct Disorder (aggression to people/animals, property destruction, theft, serious rule violations). Antisocial Personality Disorder cannot be diagnosed before age 18. Intermittent Explosive Disorder involves discrete outbursts of aggression disproportionate to provocation.

questions.stem: According to DSM-5, which specifier for Conduct Disorder indicates the most severe form with the poorest prognosis?
questions.explanation: The 'with limited prosocial emotions' specifier (callous-unemotional traits) indicates the most severe form of CD, associated with: lack of remorse/guilt, callousness/lack of empathy, unconcern about performance, and shallow/deficient affect. This specifier predicts more severe aggression, poorer treatment response, and higher risk for adult Antisocial Personality Disorder. Childhood-onset is also a risk factor but the CU traits specifier indicates particular severity. Adolescent-onset generally has better prognosis.

questions.stem: A 25-year-old man has a documented history of Conduct Disorder before age 15. Since age 18, he has shown a pervasive pattern of disregard for others' rights, deceitfulness, impulsivity, irritability, irresponsibility, and lack of remorse. The MOST appropriate diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD) requires: (1) pervasive pattern of disregard for others' rights since age 15, (2) age ≥18, AND (3) evidence of Conduct Disorder before age 15. This patient meets all criteria. Note: CD cannot be diagnosed in adults ('adult CD' doesn't exist); ODD doesn't have an 'adult type' and wouldn't explain the severity; IED involves discrete outbursts, not a pervasive pattern. The CD history requirement links ASPD to its developmental precursor.

questions.stem: Intermittent Explosive Disorder is characterized by:

options.text: Recurrent behavioral outbursts representing failure to control aggressive impulses
Aggression occurring only in the context of substance intoxication
Deliberate fire-setting for pleasure or relief

questions.explanation: IED involves recurrent behavioral outbursts representing failure to control aggressive impulses, either: (1) verbal aggression or physical aggression that doesn't damage property/injure occurring twice weekly for 3 months, OR (2) three outbursts involving damage/destruction/injury within 12 months. The aggression is impulsive/reactive (not premeditated), grossly out of proportion to provocation, and causes distress or impairment. Option D describes Pyromania.

questions.stem: Research on the developmental trajectory of conduct problems suggests that which group has the MOST persistent antisocial behavior into adulthood?
questions.explanation: Moffitt's developmental taxonomy distinguishes: (1) Life-course-persistent (LCP) offenders—early childhood onset, neuropsychological deficits, adverse environments, stable antisocial behavior across settings and into adulthood; (2) Adolescence-limited (AL) offenders—onset in adolescence, peer-influenced, time-limited (desist in early adulthood). LCP represents about 5-10% of offenders but accounts for disproportionate crime. This has implications for early intervention targeting the LCP pathway.

questions.stem: According to DSM-5, which behaviors are included in the criteria for Conduct Disorder? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Physical cruelty to people or animals
Deliberate fire-setting with intent to cause damage

questions.explanation: CD criteria fall into four categories: (1) Aggression to people/animals—bullying, fighting, cruelty, using weapons, robbery/mugging (A, C); (2) Property destruction—fire-setting, deliberate destruction (D); (3) Deceitfulness/theft—breaking in, lying, stealing; (4) Serious rule violations—staying out late, truancy, running away (E). Arguing with authority figures (B) is an ODD criterion, not CD. CD involves more serious violations than ODD.

questions.stem: Risk factors for the development of Conduct Disorder include which of the following? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Peer rejection and association with deviant peers

questions.explanation: CD risk factors span multiple domains: Family—harsh, inconsistent discipline, poor monitoring, parental psychopathology (A); Peer—rejection leading to deviant peer affiliation (B); Individual—callous-unemotional traits, low verbal IQ, difficult temperament (C); Environmental—neighborhood disadvantage, violence exposure (D). High IQ (E) is actually a protective factor, associated with better outcomes. Low verbal IQ is a risk factor.

questions.stem: Which of the following are evidence-based treatments for Oppositional Defiant Disorder? (Select ALL that apply)
questions.explanation: Evidence-based treatments for ODD/CD: PMT—training parents in behavioral management strategies (A); MST—intensive family/community intervention for serious cases (B); PSST—teaching cognitive problem-solving skills to children (D); Collaborative Problem Solving—addressing lagging skills and unsolved problems (E). Stimulant medication (C) is NOT first-line for ODD—it may help comorbid ADHD but doesn't directly treat ODD. Psychosocial interventions are primary.

questions.stem: Which statements about Kleptomania are accurate according to DSM-5? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Stealing is for personal use or monetary value
There is rising tension before the theft
There is pleasure, gratification, or relief when committing the theft
Stealing is not for anger or vengeance
Stealing occurs in response to delusions or hallucinations

questions.explanation: Kleptomania criteria: Failure to resist impulse to steal objects NOT needed for personal use or monetary value (A is incorrect—this distinguishes from ordinary theft); rising tension before theft (B); pleasure/gratification/relief at time of theft (C); not committed for anger/vengeance or in response to psychosis (D, E is incorrect). The items stolen are often discarded, given away, or hoarded. It's an impulse control disorder, not stealing for gain.

questions.stem: Callous-unemotional (CU) traits in youth are characterized by which of the following? (Select ALL that apply)
questions.explanation: DSM-5's 'limited prosocial emotions' specifier for CD captures CU traits: Lack of remorse/guilt (A)—doesn't feel bad after hurting others; Callous/lack of empathy (D)—disregards others' feelings; Unconcerned about performance (E)—doesn't care about school/work; Shallow/deficient affect (C)—doesn't express feelings except to manipulate. Excessive worry (B) is the opposite of CU traits. CU traits predict severity and treatment response.

questions.stem: Match each disorder to its defining characteristic:

columns.text: Aggression to people/animals, property destruction, theft, serious rule violations
Recurrent impulsive aggressive outbursts disproportionate to provocation
Pervasive disregard for others' rights since age 15, with CD history

questions.explanation: Key distinctions: ODD involves defiance and irritability without serious rights violations. CD involves serious violations across four categories. IED involves impulsive (not premeditated) aggressive outbursts that are grossly disproportionate. ASPD is the adult continuation of antisocial patterns, requiring both current symptoms and history of CD before age 15.

questions.stem: Match each impulse control disorder to its core behavior:

columns.text: Recurrent stealing not for gain or revenge
Deliberate fire-setting with fascination and tension relief

questions.explanation: Impulse control disorders involve failure to resist urges: Kleptomania—stealing for the act itself, not for objects' value; Pyromania—fire-setting with fascination, tension before and relief after; IED—impulsive aggression grossly out of proportion; Gambling Disorder (now in Substance-Related chapter but related)—persistent gambling despite consequences. All involve tension-reward cycles around the specific behavior.

questions.stem: For each ODD symptom category, select ALL symptoms that belong:

columns.text: Has been spiteful or vindictive at least twice in 6 months
Is often touchy or easily annoyed

questions.explanation: ODD symptom categories: Angry/Irritable Mood—loses temper, touchy/easily annoyed, angry/resentful. Argumentative/Defiant—argues with authority, defies/refuses to comply, deliberately annoys, blames others. Vindictiveness—spiteful/vindictive (only needs to occur twice in 6 months). Diagnosis requires ≥4 symptoms from any category, lasting ≥6 months, with impairment.

questions.stem: For each Conduct Disorder category, select ALL behaviors that belong:

columns.text: Lying to obtain goods or avoid obligations

questions.explanation: CD categories: Aggression—bullying, initiating fights, weapon use, physical cruelty to people/animals, stealing with confrontation, forced sexual activity. Property Destruction—fire-setting and deliberate destruction. Deceitfulness/Theft—breaking into houses/cars, lying/conning, stealing without confrontation. The fourth category (Serious Rule Violations) includes staying out, truancy, running away.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about Conduct Disorder:

Conduct Disorder involves a repetitive pattern of behavior violating others' [BLANK1] or age-appropriate societal norms. DSM-5 distinguishes between [BLANK2]-onset type (before age 10) and adolescent-onset type, with earlier onset associated with worse prognosis. The [BLANK3] specifier, indicating callous-unemotional traits, also predicts more severe course. At least [BLANK4] criteria must be present in the past 12 months, with at least one in the past [BLANK5] months.
questions.explanation: CD involves violating basic rights of others or norms/rules. DSM-5 specifies childhood-onset (<10) vs. adolescent-onset types, with childhood-onset having worse prognosis. The 'limited prosocial emotions' specifier (CU traits) indicates the most severe form. Diagnosis requires ≥3 of 15 criteria in past 12 months AND ≥1 criterion in past 6 months.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about developmental pathways to antisocial behavior:

Moffitt's taxonomy distinguishes [BLANK1]-persistent offenders from adolescence-limited offenders. The former group shows antisocial behavior beginning in [BLANK2] and continuing into adulthood, often with neuropsychological deficits and adverse early environments. Adolescence-limited offenders begin during [BLANK3] years, often influenced by peers, and typically [BLANK4] in early adulthood. Research suggests childhood-onset conduct problems with [BLANK5] traits are particularly resistant to treatment.
questions.explanation: Moffitt's taxonomy: Life-course-persistent (LCP) offenders show childhood-onset antisocial behavior continuing across the lifespan, often with neuropsychological vulnerabilities and environmental adversity. Adolescence-limited offenders begin in adolescence, are peer-influenced, and desist in early adulthood. CU traits predict treatment resistance and more severe outcomes within the LCP pathway.

questions.stem: A 14-year-old boy has a 3-year history of shoplifting, vandalizing property, and lying to his parents. Recently, he was caught breaking into cars. He shows no remorse, blames others, and appears unconcerned about consequences. He has been cruel to the family cat.
questions.centerQuestion: What is the MOST appropriate diagnosis with specifier?

options.text: Multiple CD criteria (theft, vandalism, breaking in, animal cruelty)
Only defiance and arguing, no rights violations
CU traits predict poorer treatment response
Higher risk for ASPD in adulthood
May need more intensive, specialized intervention

centerOptions.text: Conduct Disorder, childhood-onset, with limited prosocial emotions

questions.explanation: This meets CD criteria (theft, vandalism, B&E, animal cruelty). Onset before age 10 (3-year history at age 14 = started at 11) is childhood-onset type. The lack of remorse, callousness, and unconcern about consequences indicate 'limited prosocial emotions' specifier. This combination predicts: more severe aggression, poorer standard treatment response, higher ASPD risk. ASPD cannot be diagnosed before age 18.

questions.stem: A 32-year-old man frequently has explosive angry outbursts when frustrated, including yelling, throwing objects, and occasionally hitting walls. The outbursts occur 2-3 times weekly, last minutes, and are grossly out of proportion to any provocation. He feels remorseful afterward. He had conduct problems as a teen but no other current psychiatric symptoms.
questions.centerQuestion: What is the MOST likely diagnosis?

options.text: No current pervasive pattern of rights violations

questions.explanation: This is IED: recurrent aggressive outbursts (2-3/week), grossly disproportionate to provocation, impulsive not premeditated, causing distress. The remorse is actually characteristic of IED—unlike ASPD where remorse is absent. Though he had teen conduct problems, his current presentation lacks the pervasive pattern of rights violations required for ASPD. CD cannot be diagnosed in adults. ODD doesn't involve this level of aggression.

questions.stem: A clinical psychologist is reviewing diagnostic criteria for disruptive behavior disorders. Highlight the THREE accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) ODD involves serious violations of others' rights including theft and aggression. (B) Conduct Disorder criteria are organized into four categories: aggression, property destruction, deceitfulness/theft, and serious rule violations. (C) The 'limited prosocial emotions' specifier for CD indicates callous-unemotional traits. (D) Antisocial Personality Disorder can be diagnosed at age 16 if severe. (E) IED involves premeditated aggression for instrumental purposes. (F) Childhood-onset Conduct Disorder generally has worse prognosis than adolescent-onset.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (B) CD has four criterion categories; (C) LPE specifier = CU traits; (F) Childhood-onset CD has worse prognosis. Incorrect: (A) ODD involves defiance/irritability, NOT serious rights violations—that's CD; (D) ASPD requires age ≥18; (E) IED is impulsive/reactive, NOT premeditated—premeditated aggression would not be IED.

questions.stem: A child psychiatrist is reviewing evidence-based treatments. Highlight the FOUR accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) Parent Management Training is an evidence-based treatment for ODD. (B) Stimulant medication is the first-line treatment for ODD without comorbid ADHD. (C) Multisystemic Therapy is effective for serious conduct problems. (D) Youth with callous-unemotional traits respond equally well to standard treatments. (E) Problem-Solving Skills Training targets the child's cognitive deficits. (F) Family-based interventions are a cornerstone of treatment for disruptive behavior disorders. (G) Punishment-based approaches are most effective for CD.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) PMT is evidence-based for ODD; (C) MST is effective for serious CD; (E) PSST targets problem-solving deficits; (F) Family interventions are essential. Incorrect: (B) Medication isn't first-line for ODD without ADHD—psychosocial interventions are; (D) CU traits predict POORER response to standard treatments; (G) Punishment-based approaches are NOT effective—contingency management with positive reinforcement is better.

questions.stem: Arrange the typical developmental progression of externalizing disorders from EARLIEST to LATEST onset:
questions.explanation: Developmental progression: ADHD typically emerges first (preschool/early school age); ODD often follows (~ages 6-8); CD may develop next (~ages 9-14) in a subset of ODD cases; ASPD is the adult continuation (≥18) for those with CD history. This 'developmental cascade' isn't inevitable—many children with ODD don't develop CD, and early intervention can prevent progression.

questions.stem: Arrange these Conduct Disorder severity levels from MILDEST to MOST SEVERE:

options.text: Severe: many conduct problems beyond minimum, considerable harm to others
Mild: few conduct problems beyond minimum, minor harm
With limited prosocial emotions specifier (regardless of severity)

questions.explanation: CD severity: Mild—few problems beyond the diagnostic minimum, relatively minor harm. Moderate—intermediate number and harm. Severe—many conduct problems, considerable harm to others. The 'limited prosocial emotions' specifier (CU traits) indicates the most severe presentation regardless of symptom count because it predicts worse outcomes, more instrumental aggression, and poorer treatment response.

questions.stem: Review longitudinal data on developmental trajectories of antisocial behavior:

questions.question: What pattern distinguishes the LCP from AL trajectory?

options.text: LCP shows early onset and persistence; AL shows adolescent peak then decline
AL is more severe than LCP

questions.question: What does the AL trajectory suggest about most adolescent antisocial behavior?

options.text: It will inevitably lead to adult criminality
It is a time-limited phenomenon that typically desists

questions.explanation: Moffitt's trajectories: LCP shows childhood onset and relative persistence into adulthood (though declining). AL shows dramatic increase during adolescence followed by normative desistance in early adulthood. This has implications: most adolescent offenders (AL type) will 'age out' without intensive intervention, while LCP offenders need early, sustained intervention. Distinguishing trajectories informs treatment intensity.

questions.stem: Examine treatment outcome data comparing interventions for conduct problems:

questions.question: What do these data suggest about treatment efficacy?

options.text: Parent Management Training shows superior outcomes

questions.question: What pattern is shown regarding treatment maintenance?

options.text: PMT gains are largely maintained at follow-up
Individual therapy catches up to PMT

questions.explanation: The data illustrate: (1) PMT produces substantially better outcomes than non-behavioral individual therapy or treatment as usual; (2) PMT gains are largely maintained at 2-year follow-up (some slight increase but still well below pretreatment). This supports PMT as the evidence-based standard for ODD/CD. Traditional individual therapy targeting the child alone shows limited efficacy—family-level intervention is critical.

questions.stem: Categorize each behavior as characteristic of ODD or CD:

items.text: Has stolen while confronting a victim
Is often touchy or easily annoyed
Has broken into someone's house or car
Has been physically cruel to animals
Has run away from home overnight

questions.explanation: ODD symptoms: arguing, touchy/annoyed, blaming others, spiteful—involving defiance and mood without serious rights violations. CD symptoms: robbery (confrontational theft), breaking and entering, animal cruelty, running away—involving serious violations. The disorders rarely overlap symptomatically, though ODD often precedes CD developmentally. When CD criteria are met, CD is diagnosed (supersedes ODD).

questions.stem: Categorize each risk factor according to the level at which it operates:

items.text: School with high antisocial peer concentration

questions.explanation: Multi-level risk factors: Individual—neuropsychological deficits (low verbal IQ), CU traits, temperament. Family—parenting practices (harsh discipline, poor monitoring), family conflict, parental psychopathology. Community—neighborhood disadvantage, deviant peers, school context. Effective interventions often target multiple levels (e.g., MST addresses individual, family, peer, and school factors).
